title: Friday, 1st December, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Hey! Hello, hi, good morning, how are you, great to be here.

BE11:04am

Welcome to December. Here's the mighty fire-drake, Smaug™.

BE11:04am

11:05 am
BE11:05am

That's a completed mighty fire-drake, Smaug™, to be clear. The one you receive for your £295 looks like a bag of grey plastic bits.

BE11:05am

The mighty fire-drake, Smaug™ is doubtless the largest and most powerful of his kind left in Middle-earth™.
Smaug™ is built upon a stunningly detailed scenic base that depicts the vast treasures of Erebor. The Arkenstone™ and The One Ring can both clearly be seen amongst the gems and gold as Smaug™ looms over the would-be burglar Bilbo Baggins™.

BE11:06am

Yeah.

11:05 am
BE11:06am

This magnificent 42 piece miniature is hand cast using the highest quality resin (the same used by Forge World), and the most advanced techniques to produce a model with extremely fine detail. Every scale, horn and battle-scar has been expertly reproduced to create a beatifically authentic collectors piece.
Weighing in at 2.4kgs, the height of the miniature from the bottom of the base to the tip of Smaug’s™ wing is 8.4 inches (or 21.4 cm). The base is 9.2 inches (or 23.1 cm) long and 5.4 inches (or 13.3 cm) wide.

BE11:06am

Not a Smaug™ fan? Then what about the Scions of Mars?

BE11:06am

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Through mutual oaths and unbreakable vows, the Adeptus Mechanicus have forged alliances with many Knight worlds. In return for technical aid and reciprocal protection, these Houses – or Knights of the Cog as they are sometimes known – send forth their adamantine Knight-suits to honour any request made by their allies.

BE11:06am

Alphaville is managed on a similar structure.

BE11:07am

With this box, you’ll receive 3 Imperial Knights – assemble them as any combination of Warden, Paladin, Errant, Gallant or Crusader you wish, with a huge array of weapon options left over to customise any Knights you might have lying around (one can never have too many, after all…)

11:07 am
BE11:08am

I'd argue that, at £285 a pop, a person can have too many.

BE11:08am

This is all apropos of Games Workshop, of course.

BE11:08am

Which has done a year's earnings in six months.

11:08 am
BE11:09am

And is, with a 193% gain year to date, 2017 best performer (ignoring Aim).

BE11:09am

BE11:09am

We've mentioned hardly any of these companies here, it occurs .....

11:10 am
BE11:10am

... whereas we rarely shut up about the biggest fallers -- Carillion, Interserve, Provident Financial, Allied Minds ......

BE11:11am

We're misery vampires. Anyway, let's rectify that a bit.

BE11:11am

Peel Hunt:

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Games Workshop has delivered a very impressive H1 with EBIT of £38m matching last year’s full year. We are not changing our outlook for the current year, but the company is well on track to deliver on our FY forecast of £65m ahead of the important Christmas period.

BE11:11am

It is encouraging that the growth has been seen in all regions and all channels, with H1 sales +54% to £109m. Importantly the sales trend has been maintained since the 40K launch in the summer. Although it is sensible to assume the current elevated sales trend does not continue, the increase in sales of starter sets bodes well for future periods.

BE11:11am

The profit performance will have translated into a healthy cash position. The company will step up investment in the business by c£7m in order to expand capacity. Nonetheless there will still be significant excess capital to return to shareholders. We are currently forecasting a full year dividend of 120p (6% yield) and year end net cash of £20m. H1 profits will be announced on 9 January 2018.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

This is in part a sterling story, as more than 70% of Games Workshop sales come from overseas ......

BE11:12am

But it's also a management story. Kevin Rountree, the CEO, has done a spectacularly good job.

BE11:13am

He was an internal appointment in 2015, having been COO since 2011 and CFO before that ......

11:14 am
BE11:14am

And what he's done was dull and sensible. As in, threw resources at staff retention, recruitment and training.

BE11:16am

Also, I think, changed the model so there was only one person behind the counter in the average shop. Which seems to have made the Comic Book Guy and 16 Side Dice types actually talk to the customers rather than each other.

BE11:16am

So, increased sales of starter packs, the gateway drug to this stuff.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

(@Mouselet: options pricing.)

BE11:17am

Anyway, since I mention it above, want to know what the biggest gainer is on Aim this year?

BE11:17am

You'll never guess.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

BE11:18am

Yeah. Echo Energy. Done better than Bitcoin.

BE11:19am

South America onshore gas play, if I remember right.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

Was a reverse takeover.

undefined
BE11:21am

From dragons to scag.

11:20 am
Indivior PLC (INDV:LSE): Last: 401.70, up 30.9 (+8.33%), High: 420.00, Low: 398.60, Volume: 1.82m
BE11:21am

"From Smaug to scag" would've been better, right? Sorry, it's Friday, I'm tired.

BE11:22am

FDA approves RBP6000

11:22 am
BE11:22am

With a boxed warning, as expected, and pricing much as everyone had expected.

BE11:23am

This is, to catch up latecomers to the story, Extended-Release Buprenorphine

BE11:24am

Which used to be called RBP6000 but is now called Sublocade but on here we'll continue to call it Buprenorphine because calling drugs by their trade names is bad practice.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Once-monthly injectable heroin, essentially, but with most of the fun stuff removed.

BE11:26am

And the black box warning is no surprise. Here's RBC.

BE11:26am

Sublocade will have a black box warning, distribution will be limited to prevent patient self administration and patients must be initiated on conventional therapy for seven days before switching to Sublocade. We note that both dosing regimens (300mg for two months then switching to 100mg for maintenance and 300mg throughout) have been approved, with the higher dosing regimen only to be considered for those patients in which the benefits outweigh the risk. In each case, these were known/expected restrictions and do not impact our commercial model for the product. In fact we see the approval of both 300/100 and 300/300 dosing regimens as a positive given the mixed panel vote at the Adcom meeting.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

(@erlkin: I'm not an expert here, but I assume heroin's fun? Otherwise, why take it?)

BE11:28am

This is the next step in Indivior long history of trying to modify its stuff in advance of patent expiries.

BE11:28am

Back to RBC.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Whilst the news today is a clear positive we would be reticent to remind investors of upcoming generic risks to the Suboxone Film franchise, which we would still expect to have an impact on the success of Sublocade. We are next due to hear if DRL’s generic is approved in Q1/2-2018, but with the two still in court over an appeal process we see an at-risk launch as unlikely. We see a material sentiment risk to the share price should DRL’s product be approved but a material positive for Indivior if they can i) win in appeal or ii) bring DRL to the table and reach a settlement. Beyond this we then have the Alvogen case set to start Q1, with the outcome also impactful on the share price.

BE11:29am

Another consideration for investors is the upcoming potential approval of Camarus’/Braeburn’s own monthly depot product, CAM2038. Our base case assumption is approval, but given the more debatable outcome at the Adcom panel, we could see further label restrictions (or best case for Indivior, a delay) that could provide Indivior with a further head start in the market.

BE11:30am

And in terms of numbers ............

11:30 am
BE11:30am

We think peak sales of +$1.4bn possible for Sublocade (RBP-6 0 0 0 ) b y 2 0 2 5 : [... W]e are bullish on the commercial potential for Sublocade given our proprietary 77-physician survey (largely psychiatrists) indicated c40% of patients would be switched over to the long acting monthly
products. Even a er taking into considera on compe on and an eventual generic Suboxone Film launch we see peak sales of +$1.4bn as possible. We note from the Sublocade fact sheet that the wholesale acquisi on cost (WAC) price will be $1580 a month ($18,960 per year), which compares favourably with our $9k p.a. net price,
providing some room for discounting to gain formulary access. We need to do more work on the price elasticity of the market, and if a c20% discount to Sublocade’s announced price will be sufficient to gain comprehensive formulary access but, given management have likely completed this work ahead of time, we are confident on
still meeting our sales forecasts (at this price we estimate a c10% market share is required to meet $1.4bn of sales by 2025).

BE11:31am

So Indivior hasn't set 2018 guidance yet .....

BE11:32am

... one assumes they'll be pushing this stuff onto the market as quick as possible, so there might be a bit of marketing cost at the front end that I'm not seeing mentioned in many analyst notes.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Given $1,580 per month is pretty big hurdle.

BE11:33am

Morgan Stanley .......

BE11:33am

Current price, applying a 30% discount for net pricing would imply a market share of 5% to reach $1bn of sales. Assuming WAC price as net price would imply market share of 3-4% to reach guidance of $1bn peak sales. While we view pricing as a potential obstacle to rapid uptake, we acknowledge the clear medical benefit the drug provides and the fact that from a market share perspective, $1bn peak sales appears conservative, despite our caution.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily markets live with the markets and the live.

undefined
BE11:35am

Hi there,

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Hi!

BE11:35am

Next year recreational marijuana will be legal in Canada. For entrepreneurs and investors, it represents a huge new investment opportunity, with some predicting a $20 billion profit spree in Canada alone. Globally this number could reach $200 billion plus.

But where specifically are the opportunities for high returns for investors?

BE11:35am

Uh, I don't know?

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Real Vision recently went on a road trip across Canada with Alan Gertner to find out. Gertner is a former Google exec who quit to start a legal marijuana company called Tokyo Smoke.

BE11:36am

Oh.

BE11:36am

According to Gertner, “This is the next trillion-dollar industry. Cannabis will be bigger than alcohol. Cannabis will be bigger than tobacco. And this is just the beginning.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Sounds nonsense! Where do I find out more?

BE11:36am

To find out more about this investment opportunity click the button below and watch FREE excerpts of the documentary.

BE11:36am

https://realvision...bc2cd&e=ec6bdf544e

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Thanks!

BE11:37am

Tune in next week for more conversations with my email inbox.

undefined
11:37 am
BE11:37am

So, what else?

BE11:38am

Babcock currently leading us down.

Babcock International Group PLC (BAB:LSE): Last: 674.50, down 22.5 (-3.23%), High: 682.00, Low: 672.00, Volume: 1.09m
11:38 am
BE11:38am

Been an absolute stinker for a few weeks, has Babcock

BE11:38am

In a way that goes far beyond concerns about UK defence spending.

BE11:40am

People have been asking some difficult questions about cash generation and organic growth, which we touched on a bit here: https://www.ft.com...-b781-794ce08b24dc

11:40 am
BE11:40am

As of today, Morgan Stanley turns cautious.

BE11:41am

Citing "limited visibility on growth and margins, [and] accounting concerns impacting sentiment"

BE11:41am

The idea here seems to be that Babcock is looking a bit Capita-ish.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

As in, its accounting treatments aren't as clear and clean as you'd like, particularly when contracts start drifting off to the right.

BE11:43am

[W]e lack conviction on the outlook for margin and returns given the rising capital intensity of the model and use of balance sheet to drive growth. We would be reluctant to add fresh money to the sector, so given these dynamics we downgrade to Babcock Equal- weight.

BE11:44am

In theory, we should remain Overweight a cheap stock with high barriers to entry that continues to deliver mid-single digit growth. However, a negative outlook would reference challenging end markets, reliance on the client relationship with the UK government, whose decisions may influence the direction of the industry and opaque accounting trends. We take a more cautious approach, accepting that this could be "capitulating" on an Overweight at the point of maximum pessimism. But we think the discount to fair value is now so wide that investors can wait until there is evidence of a sustained improvement in the risk profile.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

The note doesn't go into too much detail about the difficulties one has getting a clear view of Babcock.

BE11:45am

Only a couple of examples, such as "reported margins conceal a more volatile progression for the component parts, which also raises concerns over how profit recognition is decided.

BE11:45am

"For example, over the last 6 years the margin decline in the group business is almost offset by changes in the JV margin, which makes it difficult to be certain over the medium-term direction of travel."

11:46 am
BE11:46am

In part, this is a structural problem for the outsourcing industry.

BE11:48am

As in, you take a bath on margins in the first years of a long-term contract that should normalise as you hit milestones, which makes valuations of the project life pretty fraught.

BE11:49am

See also receivables. Babcock has unbilled receivables of £347m at the end of FY17, which is ~7% of sales, notes MOST.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

[W]hilst the headline trend in total unbilled receivables has been stable to declining over the last 7 years, certain balances, such as accrued income, have been growing ahead of sales. Our previous research shows that the level of unbilled receivables is not a problem in isolation, but rather slowing end market growth is typically the catalyst for provisions if contracts have been traded aggressively.

BE11:51am

Also: H1 receivables balance increased by 24% vs. ~6% revenue growth, "suggesting that some form of credit extension is being is being used to drive sales"

BE11:52am

All of this will look rather familiar to investors in other oursourcers, at least one of which I've already mentioned up page.

11:52 am
undefined
BE11:53am

Cripes, look at the time, session's flying by today.

BE11:54am

Could I direct you towards this excellent piece on Unilever from Scheherazade overnight: https://www.ft.com...-8c9a-d9c0a5c8d5c9

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Which I mention in part because Colgate still seems to be a popular subject among the gossips.

BE11:56am

We've heard speculation often -- such as https://seekingalp...-colgate-palmolive and https://www.street...urce/13132109.html -- about how Unilever might go for Colgate.

BE11:57am

Not sure how that idea fits with the succession planning around Paul Polman, or around Unilever's commitment to keeping cash returns going. Not sure how buying a soap maker that trades at 17x EV/EBITDA fits either. However, I note the theory.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Other (predictable) theories involve 3G etc, but again they're just complete speculation right now. SocGen turned seller on Colgate this week, incidentally.

BE11:59am

We trim our EPS forecasts by c.5% for 2018-19 as we expect restarting growth to prove expensive. Colgate trades on 24.3x 18e P/E vs Global Staples
on 20.6x. This looks a full valuation in the absence of strategic M&A given Colgate’s weak earnings growth, and we downgrade our rating from Hold to Sell on a $66 TP (was $72) as we now value the stock at par to the sector on 2019e EPS (-6% 12m TSR).

undefined
12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

Let me check the middays and then let's push off.

BE12:01pm

Oh, there was Inmarsat. Mentioned earlier.

BE12:02pm

Jefferies has a fantasy M&A note out along the lines of, "sticking DISH and Inmarsat together is a pretty stupid idea but at this price even pretty stupid ideas begin to make some sense."

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

The fall in the Inmarsat share price now outweighs the evident dis-synergies and clunking industrial logic of a bid from EchoStar. The "earnings penalty" from holding so much cash must now also be unbearable for EchoStar shareholders. We believe there is merit in doing the merger analysis. We conclude that a £10 per share offer balances all interests (though we estimate EchoStar could bid as high as £15 and still see year 3 FCF per share accretion pre-synergies

BE12:04pm

Once, just once, I'd like an M&A conference call with management to begin, "this deal has evident dis-synergies and clunking industrial logic. But, hey, it's cheap."

BE12:05pm

Here's the maths.

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

BE12:05pm

BE12:06pm

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Giles Thorne's the analyst on that.

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 504.50, up 21.6 (+4.47%), High: 515.00, Low: 485.90, Volume: 2.52m
undefined
12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Okay, that's enough. Let's knock this on the head.

BE12:07pm

Thanks for all your comments, both today and this week.

BE12:09pm

See you Monday. Afternoon all.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

We are encouraged
by this approval and, as Indivior defends Suboxone film, we expect the story to shift more and more towards Sublocade as it grows. The company warns that uptake may be slow given the need for physician and patient education and, while we need to see consensus expectations for 2018, our feedback from investors would lead us to believe that risk is skewed to the upside, if the company can over-deliver on patient switches.
